title: Statuette of Hercules
description: The weary hero Hercules stands at rest after completing his Eleventh Labor: stealing three golden apples from a tree guarded by nymphs known as the Hesperides. Here, he holds the apples behind his back. Originally his left arm was supported by his club, which was cast separately and is now missing. This statuette is a copy of the lost masterpiece of Herakles by the Greek sculptor Lysippos, which became one of the definitive images of Hercules in classical antiquity and into the Renaissance in the 15th century.
publication_history:
Edward H. Merrin Gallery, Classical Art: Greek. Roman, Etruscan, sale cat. (New York, 1977), cover lot and p. 31 (ill.).

Art Institute of Chicago, Annual Report: 1978-79 (Art Institute of Chicago, 1979), p. 35.

Art Institute of Chicago, Mosaic: March/April 1987 (Art Institute of Chicago, 1987), p. 6.

Karen B. Alexander and Mary Greuel. Private Taste in Ancient Rome: Selections from Chicago Collections. Exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1990), cat. 22.

Cornelius C. Vermeule III, Roman Art, Museum Studies: Ancient Art at The Art Institute of Chicago 20, no. 1 (1994), pp. 69-70, cat. 46 (ill.). 46.

Karen Alexander, "The New Galleries of Ancient Art at the Art Institute of Chicago," Minerva vol. 5, no. 3 (May/June, 1994), p. 33, fig. 10. 

Cornelius Vermeule, "Roman Provincial Coins: The Statues in the Temples and Shrines," The Celator 16, 15 (January, 2002), pp. 8, 10, fig. 3A. 

Karen B. Alexander, "From Plaster to Stone: Ancient Art at the Art Institute of Chicago," in Karen Manchester, Recasting the Past: Collecting and Presenting Antiquities at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago; New Haven: Yale University Press, 2012), pp. 33, 39.

Sandra E. Knudsen, “Cat. 143 Statuette of Hercules: Curatorial Entry,” in Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2016).

John Twilley, “Cat. 143 Statuette of Hercules: Technical Report,” in Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2016).
exhibition_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, Myth and Legend in Classical Art, Gallery 101A, March 1, 1987-August 31, 1987.

Art Institute of Chicago, The Human Figure in Greek and Roman Art: From the Permanent Collection, January 13–February 21, 1990, no cat.

Art Institute of Chicago, Private Taste in Ancient Rome: Selections from Chicago Collections, March 3–September 16, 1990, cat. 22.

Art Institute of Chicago, Of Gods and Glamour: The Mary and Michael Jaharis Galleries of Greek, Roman, and Byzantine Art, Gallery 152, November 11, 2012-present.
provenance_text: Possibly ex-collection Edward H. Merrin Gallery 1977 [according to notes in curatorial file]; sold to B.C. Holland of Objects Inc., Chicago, by June 5, 1978 [receipt no. 36220 in curatorial file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1978.
department_title: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
category_titles: Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium
section_titles: Cat. 143  Statuette of Hercules, mid- to late 1st century A.D.
